findings.title: EmptyByteArrayCopy
findings.description: Copying an empty byte array (or string) from memory or calldata to storage can result in data corruption if the target array's length is increased subsequently without storing new data.

findings.title: DynamicArrayCleanup
findings.description: When assigning a dynamically-sized array with types of size at most 16 bytes in storage causing the assigned array to shrink, some parts of deleted slots were not zeroed out.

findings.title: Solidity assert violation.
findings.description: The contract contains an assertion that can be violated, potentially leading to unintended behavior or security risks.

findings.title: Incorrect ERC20 implementation.
findings.description: The contract does not conform to the ERC20 standard.

findings.title: Outdated compiler version.
findings.description: Using outdated solidity compiler versions can lead to known bugs and vulnerabilities, such as EmptyByteArrayCopy and DynamicArrayCleanup.

findings.title: No or floating compiler version set
findings.description: Using an outdated or unspecified solidity compiler version can lead to potential security vulnerabilities and bugs.

findings.title: Use of right-to-left-override control character
findings.description: The contract uses a right-to-left-override control character which can cause issues with code readability and potentially lead to security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Shadowing of built-in symbol.
findings.description: The code shadows a built-in symbol, which can lead to unexpected behavior and errors.

findings.title: Incorrect constructor name.
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: State variable shadows another state variable
findings.description: A state variable has the same name as another state variable, which can lead to confusion and unintended behavior.

findings.title: Local variable shadows a state variable.
findings.description: In Solidity, when a local variable has the same name as a state variable, it can lead to unintended behavior and bugs. This finding highlights instances where a local variable is shadowing a state variable, potentially causing issues in the contract's functionality.

findings.title: Function parameter shadows a state variable
findings.description: A function parameter has the same name as a state variable, which can lead to confusion and unintended behavior.

findings.title: Named return value shadows a state variable
findings.description: The naming of a return value is identical to an existing state variable, potentially leading to confusion and unintended behavior.

findings.title: Unary operation without effect
findings.description: The unary operation in the Solidity code has no effect.

findings.title: Unary operation directly after assignment
findings.description: The unary operation is performed immediately after a variable assignment, which can lead to unintended behavior or incorrect results.

findings.title: Unused state variable
findings.description: The contract has a state variable that is declared but not used anywhere in the code.

findings.title: Unused local variable
findings.description: The code contains a locally declared variable that is not being utilized.

findings.title: Function visibility is not set
findings.description: The function does not have its visibility explicitly set, which can lead to unintended access or behavior.

findings.title: State variable visibility is not set
findings.description: The visibility of state variables has not been explicitly defined, which can lead to unintended access and potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Use of deprecated functions: call code(), sha3(), …
findings.description: The contract uses deprecated functions such as call code(), sha3(), etc.

findings.title: Use of deprecated global variables (msg.gas, ...)
findings.description: The contract uses deprecated global variables such as msg.gas, which can lead to unexpected behavior and security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Use of deprecated keywords (throw, var)
findings.description: The contract uses deprecated keywords 'throw' and 'var', which can lead to compatibility issues and unexpected behavior.

findings.title: Incorrect function state mutability.
findings.description: The function's state mutability is incorrectly set, which can lead to unexpected behavior and potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Does the code conform to the Solidity styleguide
findings.description: The code does not follow the recommended coding practices outlined in the Solidity style guide.

findings.title: Timestamp Comparison
findings.description: The Burner constructor uses timestamp for comparisons

findings.title: Dangerous comparisons:
findings.description: Using block.timestamp for comparisons

findings.title: Divide before multiply:
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: Incorrect equality:
findings.description: Uses a dangerous strict equality in conditional statements.

findings.title: External Function Declaration
findings.description: The renounceOwnership() function should be declared as an external function.

findings.title: transferOwnership(address) should be declared external
findings.description: The function transferOwnership(address) in Ownable.sol should be declared as an external function.
